segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā tisso bhagavato pitucchāputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi dukkhī dummano assūni pavattayamāno. Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ tissaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Venerable Tissa—the Buddha’s cousin on his father’s side—went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. He was miserable and sad, with tears flowing. Then the Buddha said to him:

segments.pli: “kiṃ nu kho tvaṃ, tissa, ekamantaṃ nisinno dukkhī dummano assūni pavattayamāno”ti?
segments.en: “Tissa, why are you sitting there so miserable and sad, with tears flowing?”

segments.pli: “Tathā hi pana maṃ, bhante, bhikkhū samantā vācāyasannitodakena sañjambharimakaṃsū”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, it’s because the mendicants on all sides provoke me with barbed words.”

segments.pli: “Tathāhi pana tvaṃ, tissa, vattā no ca vacanakkhamo;
segments.en: “That’s because you admonish others, but don’t accept admonition yourself.

segments.pli: na kho te taṃ, tissa, patirūpaṃ kulaputtassa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitassa, yaṃ tvaṃ vattā no ca vacanakkhamo.
segments.en: As a gentleman who has gone forth in faith from the lay life to homelessness, it’s not appropriate for you to admonish others without accepting admonition yourself.

segments.pli: Etaṃ kho te, tissa, patirūpaṃ kulaputtassa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitassa:
‘yaṃ tvaṃ vattā ca assa vacanakkhamo cā’”ti.
segments.en: admonish others and accept admonition yourself.”
That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
segments.en: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
“Why are you angry? Don’t be angry!
It’s better to not be angry, Tissa.
For this spiritual life is lived
in order to remove anger, conceit, and denigration.”

suttaplex.blurb: Venerable Tissa admonished others but got upset when he was admonished. The Buddha encourages him to let go of his anger.
